posts.com:
This board is dedicated to the discussion of history and the other humanities such as philosophy, religion, law, classical artwork, archeology, anthropology, ancient languages, etc. Please use /lit/ for discussions of literature. Threads should be about specific topics, and the creation of "general" threads is discouraged.

For the purpose of determining what is history, please do not start threads about events taking place less than 25 years ago. Historical discussions should be focused on past events, and not their contemporary consequences. Discussion of modern politics, current events, popular culture, or other non-historical topics should be posted elsewhere. General discussions about international culture should go on /int/.

/his/ is not /pol/, and Global Rule #3 is in effect. Do not try to treat this board as /pol/ with dates. Blatant racism and trolling will not be tolerated, and a high level of discourse is expected. History can be examined from many different conflicting viewpoints; please treat other posters with respect and address the content of their post instead of attacking their character.

When discussing history, please reference credible source material, and provide as much supporting information as possible in your posts.

>>14342430
An intensified variant of nationalism that sees nations as the base functional unit of human organization, and seeks to unify the various components of a given nation (industry, politics, religion, military, etc) into a single unified authority under the logic that the power of the nation would be more effectively wielded if the populace and the state were welded together. Further, there is often a transformative element to it, in that it seeks to also remake the nation into a new form - which sets it apart from more 'traditionalist' ideas and marks it as a decidedly modern one.

The name comes from that Roman symbol, the fasces, which makes sense considering the whole 'we must bundle together the nation's power to be STRONGER' thing.

Alas, the efforts to concentrate power and cleanly map the idealized conception of a nation onto reality oft require distasteful policies or engender conflict among nations to implement, so it is not a very popular idea these days. Especially among those who adhere to ideologies that see nations as less fundamental than fascists do (and thus see fascist policies as unnecessary or even counterproductive) or to those who owe loyalty to groups - be they religious or cultural or intellectual or what have you - that straddle national borders and are thus likely to end up on the shit list of any hypothetical fascists who achieve power.

Regarding France :
-Champagne : screwed over economically as early as the late middle ages, when overland trade dwindled in favour of Rhenish and oversea trade through Gibraltar. The region has had nothing to offer other than farmland today, and it is a pretty barren and depressing place because of that.
-Western Burgundy : half of it is the Morvan forest, which is self explanatory. The rest, on the Loire, lost any semblance of economic relevance when the railway made other parts of the country easier to reach for freight or commerce without having to use the Loire (not that the Loire was ever a big commercial river, it’s tricky to navigate).
-Berry : see Champagne : exact same story : pure farmland, far from any strategic or commercial axis. If that wasn’t enough, the region suffered from the wars of religion quite heavily.
-Massif central : well it’s a mountain range duh.
-Perigord and Aquitaine : forests, hills, hilly forests and forested hills. Do the maths. Any international trade would have gone through Bordeaux and most trade with Spain would have gone through catalonia and the med, rather than the rugged Basque country.

In the spring of 1864, Tianjing was besieged and dangerously low on food supplies. The pilgrims are from Plymouth, not Jamestown. If you're talking about the actual pilgrims, they tried to grow traditional crops they were used to at first but the soil in at least that part of New England was of a different kind and required specific techniques to make things grow.
>These skilled Native American farmers knew how to get the most out of the poor coastal soil and taught the Pilgrims to do the same. Unlike the soil of southern England, which is deep, nutrient-rich, loamy and easy to hand till, the soil in coastal Massachusetts is shallow, sandy and stony, making it hard to work by hand, according to the Soil Science Society of America.
>The Wampanoag grew corn, squash, and beans – crops known as the “Three Sisters” that make a potent growing team, especially in poor, sandy soil that doesn’t retain nutrients or water. The three plants work well together to create fertile soil. Beans are nitrogen fixers, pulling nitrogen from the air, and with the help of soil microbes, turning the nitrogen into plant food. The corn provides the beans a support on which to grow and the squash helps in water retention and with weed control.

For organisms that reproduce sexually, their entire evolutionary development hinges on finding a partner to fuck and spread their genes.

Many may think that it is actually survival that is the end all be all in life, but that’s just because in most cases, the well being and survival of adult species is conducive to reproduction. There are moths that have no mouths and are doomed to die, but they are that way because they reproduce before they die. They reproduce before their deaths would have any impact on their reproduction

This is why humans have shitty wisdom teeth. By the time a primitive human’s teeth betray them, they would’ve fucked and spread their genes since they where 13.

The seemingly inherent morals that many religions acknowledge are no different; these behaviors were conducive to reproduction

Sure, a cave grug could dominate others and spread his genes by murdering his fellow men and taking their women, but this behavior is hardly able to foster any sort of cooperation between men. You can only go so far on your own. When you aren’t killing your fellow man and raping their wives, you can trade pelts, share food, build shelter, share techniques in stone tools, and find a level of success and ultimately increased chance of reproduction that is far greater than what a single unsociable man would find. Over the years, the benefits of these morals out-competed the rape grugs and as result, we now have those morals inherent to us, much like how herding dogs will guide sheep

Also note that these concepts of morality have historically pertained to our own tribe. The idea of not pillaging and raping an opposing tribe is a relatively new thing

If ideology necessarily determined foreign policy, Hitler and Stalin would never have joined hands any more than Richelieu and the Sultan of Turkey would have three centuries earlier. But common geopolitical interest is a powerful bond, and it was pushing the old enemies, Hitler and Stalin, inexorably together.

When it happen, the democracies were incredulous; their stunned surprise indicated that they had no better understanding of Stalin's mentality than they had of Hitler's. Stalin's career, like Hitler's, had been forged on the fringes of society, though it took him much longer to reach absolute power. Hitler's reliance on demagogic brilliance caused him to stake everything on a single throw of the dice. Stalin prevailed by undermining his rivals from deep within the communist bureaucracy, where the other contenders for powers had ignored him because they did not at first view the sinister figure from Georgia as a serious rival. Hitler succeeded by overwhelming his associates with elemental single-mindedness; ; Stalin accrued power by dint of implacable anonymity.

Hitler transposed his Bohemian work habits and mercurial personality into decision-making, endowing his government with a fitful and occasionally dilettantish quality. Stalin incorporated the rigorous catechisms of his early religious training into the brutal exegeses of the Bolshevik world view, and transformed ideology into an instrument of political control. Hitler thrived on the succour of the adoration of the masses. Stalin was far too paranoid to rely on so personal an approach. He craved ultimate victory far more than immediate approbation, and preferred to achieve it by destroying, one by one, all his potential rivals.

Beyond these psychological aspects, Stalin's characters had a philosophical core which made him nearly incomprehensible to Western leaders. As an old Bolshevik, he had suffered imprisonment, exile, and privation on behalf of his convictions for decades before coming to power. Priding themselves on having a superior insight into the dynamics of history, the Bolsheviks saw their role as helping along the objective historical process. In their view, the difference between themselves and noncommunist was akin to the difference between a scientist and laymen. In analysing physical phenomena, the scientist does not actually bring them about; his understanding of why they occur enables him occasionally to manipulate the process, though never according to anything but the phenomena's own inherent laws. In the same spirit, the Bolsheviks though of themselves as scientists of history-helping to make its dynamics apparent, perhaps even to speed them up, but never to change their immutable direction.

Before I refute OP's particular attack on the Christian faith I want to stress the weight of the objection by illustrating how unsatisfactory Dirk's response is. The underlying presupposition here is that a proposition which has not yet been proven or disproven is assumed to be false. I imagine this is an unwitting influence from atheism, since Christians have far too often allowed the atheists in that dispute to lessen the burden of proof which they bear by letting them justify their professed unbelief in God by claiming there has been insufficient evidence to prove His existence; however it is mistaken that a proposition not proven or disproven is assumed to be false, it is assumed to have a truth value equal to its negation. So perhaps the atheist has succeeded in justifying his own personal unbelief, but at the same time he has succeeded in stripping himself of any basis to object to the Christian's belief, since his unbelief apparently has no more evidentiary basis than belief. Likewise, if our sole response to the tranny is that he has not proven his case, perhaps we are vindicated in not embracing his perversion, but we have also vindicated him in not repudiating it.

The main issue is not that there’s hybrid or hard to define identities.
The issue is when we take the exception to define the norm.
Let’s apply the same pattern to a bike. Bikes are an individual mean of transportation pro pulsed by the person riding it. What about bikes with two seats? You may say. They are bikes too. But we cannot define bikes as a mean of transportation for two people just because a few bikes have two seats.
It’s a problem of pairing phenomena with its optimal identity according to its teleology in order to maintain a coherent ontological structure.
The issue of the fall is rooted in this problem. Adam is alone in the garden and he names the creatures as God told him to. But he doesn’t have a feedback mechanism to make sure he is naming things properly. God then gives him a woman who will be closer to nature and will mediate between Adam and the creatures. >at an ever-diminishing well of manpower that *would've replenished* if they weren't fucking burning it on constant warfare and taxing shit to hell and back.
Your fatal lack of understanding of massive difference between Central Italian culture in the Republic and Empire is showing. The amount of men from Central Italy mobilised reached something about 30% in the Republic, by the 2nd century it was less than 5%.
>They didn't really seem to understand currency, very much, either, what with all the debasement
They understood it very well, most people on here don't seem to understand that debasement is not a bad thing per se. It increases the amount of coin available to the Emperor to use. The attempt to increase purity in coinage was usually a bad thing for the Emperor, as in the reigns of Valens and Valentinian when they had to sell Imperial estates to make up for the loss in real Imperial revenue.
> locking people into their professions on a generation-to-generation basis
This only actually applied to the Army and the Curial class and was easy enough to circumvent.
>capping prices into place
These have quite literally always existed. Diocletian's price controls were an extreme version of what they already had, and it didn't last and wasn't even implemented in most places.

As I learn more and more, Romans. The Greeks are the springboard every budding person takes before they fall into the pool that is researching classical antiquity. I've seen a relatively new mindset that the Pax Romana is boring to learn about and that the later empire is more interesting, and while I agree that it's cool, I prefer the early part of the empire because it's like seeing a child take it's first steps. He stumbles a bit, and you end up with a Caligula or Nero, but overall, things are pretty good. I'm kind of a contrarian in the sense that I actually think the Flavian dynasty was the best of the four Pax Romana-era dynasties.

My favorite period of Greece is the classical period, and if you expand that into the broader "Hellenistic" period, then the post-Alexander world is extremely interesting, and the wars of the Diadochi and hearing about all the intermingling is really cool, especially hearing about stuff like the Seleucids using war elephants and to a lesser extent the Mithridaitic wars, the Hasmonean kingdom. Middle classical antiquity is like the high school of the big players of the Mediterranean, full of the exploration of identity, struggle and growing pains.

Presbyterianism, for example -- there is only supposed to be one singular established Presbyterian church, with each presbytery having its singular geographic region, similar to the domain of a bishop, which works in cohort with the state. This was what the Westminster Assembly was originally about, to create the new state religion of England, and it specifically notes that the state has the power to call church councils in its Confession. Some modern Presbyterian denominations have removed this, but their ecclesiology exists in tension with their function as merely one denomination among many. How do overlapping presbyteries from different church bodies make sense? This just an establishmentarian holdover. And there is no establishmentarianism without infant baptism, because infant baptism functions as the mark of citizenship and civil order.

"Based on haplotype prediction, both samples can be classified into haplogroup E-M78 (E1b1b1a1) which was confirmed by testing the M78 SNP marker.

The E-M78 haplogroup may have been formed about 13,400 years ago (Adamov et al., 2015). Remains belonging to the E-M78 subgroup, dating from about 7000 years ago, were discovered in Avellaner cave, Spain (Lacan et al., 2011). Another E-M78 sample from the Sopot culture was found in Hungary (5000-4800 BCE) (Szécsényi-Nagy, 2015). This indicates that E-M78 men most likely arrived with Neolithic farmers from the Fertile Crescent to Europe and even Asia (Battaglia et al., 2009). Within a few centuries, haplogroup E-V13 became one of the most widespread male lineages in Europe, reaching far beyond the borders of Europe and the Mediterranean, as Asia (Cruciani et al., 2007)."

"4. Conclusion
We have successfully identified the DNA profile of the last two male members of the renowned Central European Hunyadi family, who have an ancient Neolithic genetic heritage at the genomic level. The Y-chromosomal E1b1b1a1b1a6a1c ∼ (E-BY4281) haplogroup, which characterizes the Hunyadi family, will provide clues for the attempt to identify the remains of Matthias Hunyadi, among the remains from the ossarium adjacent to the site of the destroyed basilica at Székesfehérvár, Hungary."

I don't know too much about Judaism, so I won't speak about it. I can speak on Christianity and Islam though.
Between the two of them, Islam is MUCH more legalistic. Islam has general tendency to teach morality in terms of specific rules and laws. "Do x, y, and z, but don't do a, b, or c". A lot of other parts of Islamic morality and values come downstream from that. Recall that Muhammad conquered territory and had to build a state, so making those kinds of legal judgements wouldn't have been uncommon for him. Christianity, on the other hand, is more prone to speak in broad moral and philosophical statements. Christianity gives us the moral lesson, and then its our job to apply it practically.
This makes sense when you consider where that Christianity puts the focus on orthodoxy (believing the right things), whereas in Islam, the general focus is on orthopraxy (doing the right things). Consider the two different views on salvation. In Christianity, salvation comes from faith in God, and belief in Jesus's deity, death, and resurrections. Through that, sins are forgiven and salvation is achieved (simply put). In Islam, belief in the one God who's messenger was Muhammad is certainly important, but salvation isn't achieved through that belief. Rather, after you die, God will judge your soul based on the good and bad things you did in life. Islam is not a guarantee of salvation, but a instruction manual of what to do to get the best chance of achieving it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I read somewhere a theory that the Odin figure was an incorrectly assigned title. It states, effectively, Odin was a term designating High King or Chief of Chiefs, pulling from specific references made regarding the Germanic invasion of Rome. It states that these bands gathered together in coordinated attack seemingly from nowhere with no particular instigation against them all simultaneously, leading this individual to belief that they were rallied by a single man or rather the efforts of a single man, titled Odin.
From there it argues that Odin, possibly being a title, was assigned to the god Wodinn, as he was the chief of gods, but it was not his name. Similar to the use of words designating "Lord" that fit for Carthaginian/Phoenician gods. It would then be theorized that because of linguistic and cultural differences that the figure Wodinn was misunderstood and over time inherited the faculties of other gods. Or that Odin, Chief of Chiefs, described multiple gods over a period of time like the various Kings of old, with differing specialties and personalities that then became the soup of one figure.

I do not assign value to the theory as good or bad, merely as interesting enough to share.

Anatoly Lieberman made a god sum of this.
According to an ancient belief, a procession of dead bodies flew through the air or rode on horseback. Such a procession was called *wōðu- […] The demon chasing the dead, or in other tales leading them, could have a theriomorphic form: half man, half horse (or he could be a man eating a horse. […] The demon of the *wōðu- was also called *wōðu-. Various reflexes of this name turned up in the Modern West and North Germanic languages. […] Later, individual demons (supernatural objects of cults) gained in prominence, and a special suffix of Indo-European origin began to be used in their names. This is how *Wōðanaz came into being…
In terms of timeline, Liberman says:
Assuming that *Wōðanaz was [an active god of death and a great war god], he must have achieved this status on the continent before Tacitus.
And also:
By the time Tacitus’s informants began recording West Germanic higher mythology, *Wōðanaz had become an anthropomorphic deity surrounded by other gods, all of whom could be compared with the gods of the Romans.

What I will add is that for Odin to have attained his place of prominence by the time of Tacitus, and also for him to have transformed from a theriomorphic being into an anthropomorphic one that point, IMO, that would probably indicate an “earliest” origin of at least a couple thousands of years earlier, if not much longer.

All IE pantheons have some totally unique things going on. Among the Germanic peoples one thing that interests me is how Odin and Fryer/Ingvi each have attributes of both Apollo and Dionysus. Odin is an ascetic, he seeks to understand and make mortals more perfect (in his own way). Even the animals associated with Odin are similar to Apollo. This is an incredible motif from the unconscious and intuition, to remind us that we are at base hunters. The wolves and the ravens are our symbiotes in a pre-agricultrual sense.

Fryer is the only proper equivalent of Dionysus outside of the Greco-Roman sphere in his symbolism and cosmic function. But still it's as some have suspected; Odin became a consolidating deity similar to Ahura Mazda and Yahweh, taking cosmic function and cultural importance from other gods, especially those such as Freyr, Tyr and Thor. Evola was right, the Nordic world view was an involution (in the esoteric sense). Imagine if Nordics got over their disgust of cities sooner and urbanized.and took to the seas sooner. >>14339924
>Did they invent the technologies, or were they taught them? Provide evidence for your conclusion

Well, in the case of agriculture, we can trace the domestication of species through genetic testing.

It shows humans going from gathering wild grain species, to planting them as part of a semi-nomadic foraging strategy, to eventually committing to full time sedentary agriculture. Note that this took a long time to happen, because for most groups, hunting and gathering was a better survival strategy than farming.

In the case of writing, it emerged in Egypt and China as the extension of symbols that were used for religious and ceremonial purposes. In China, we have "oracle bones" that existed thousands of years before true writing. In Egypt, there was the famous "scorpion kings" who used the scorpion as the sigil of the royal house. In Sumeria, what would become cuneiform writing began as a series of tokens used to track grain. It slowly became used for more and more abstract things, and eventually became a full writing system.

As for metalworking, it began with copper and gold, because you don't need to mix them with anything and they have low enough melting points to melt in a decent sized bonfire. Once regional trade networks became more advanced, some nigga discovered that mixing copper and bronze created bronze, and the bronze age began.

If there was some pre-existing civilization, we would expect these cultures to begin with fully fledged writing, completely domesticated crops, and ironworking (which requires more know-how but is infinitely cheaper and more effective). This is what happened after the Bronze Age Collapse, in which most of the first wave of civilizations were destroyed. The cultures afterwards used the much more advanced technologies instead of building from scratch.

The line between "farming" and "gathering" isn't very exact. Humans have been collecting wild grains forever. It's a small step from that to just dumping leftovers in fertile areas (in particular, the regions left behind by falling lake and river waters) so you have more to gather next year.

Also, a lot of shit is believed to have sprouted up in garbage dumps, because humans would collect wild edibles, dump what was left, and then the seeds would grow more plants in the garbage areas.

So up until the weather improved enough that staying in one place and farming as the primary source of food became a viable meta, these kinds of pseudo-farming practices were what people did.

Yes, actually kind of silly how they kept the name "Prussia"
Initially it was to bypass HRE rules about not being a "King" of a territory inside the HRE, so one could be "Elector" of Brandenburg inside the HRE but "King" of Prussia that was outside. Bbut after 1806 that was not technically necessary anymore but they still kept the name "Kingdom of Prussia"

>capitalism created wokism
This is arguably the most retarded argument ever. Capitalism decided to create new identities and split their customer base, thus increasing costs and reducing profit, because... they just did? Splitting the family is more complex, culturally it doesn't really make any sense. economically it is ambiguous: female employment always existed, it just went into overdrive during WW2 due to the literal lack of labour force needed to sustain demand. Post-war, an increase in labour supply (or in Marxian terms, "a reserve army of labour") would mean a lower cost per labourer, which at once means both higher profits and lower consumption in case there aren't big enough economic units to consume it. Disrupting the family in this case is then completely counterproductive to capitalism's intentions and laws, and to that it must be added the decreasing amount of births, which lower the labour force and bring increased taxes, stifling profits and consumption. to sustain the ever increasing pensions. Capitalism arguably did not create migration either, at most took advantage of it to bolster the already existing labour force. Already rich countries attract immigration, it's not immigration which creates rich countries. All that is taking capitalism as an easily discernable system and not as it actually is, a net of human relations regulated by clear contracts and treaties that can hardly be separated by the culture it is in. To say that one can predict its future by knowing its inner "laws of motion" is to ignore its human character and to ironically reify something that isn't, which is why Marxists can't for the sake of themselves ever get a unified view of anything, except of the French Revolutions and the German Peasant War, on which their prophets Marx (pbuh) and Engels (pbuh) directly wrote.

I'll answer OP's question since clearly none of you know about this.
The answer is yes and no Yes in that the Garamantes would raid deep into the Sahara on chariot and horseback in order to both raid for slaves and trade with locals. Cave art from the Tichitt tradition who archaeologically speaking were the "Ethiopians" in the text depict men on horseback attacking and Tifinagh inscriptions exist obviously created by the Garamantes. The captives were most likely used for the building of the desert aquifers the Garamantes relied on as well as domestic purposes.
I would also say No because in the Garamantes settlement of Fewer there is a bunch of pottery done in the same style as in the Tichitt tradition further south suggesting the potters might have came to the region as migrants.
